items.title: When I created Claude Code as a side project back in September 2024, I had no idea it would grow to ...
items.content:
When I created Claude Code as a side project back in September 2024, I had no idea it would grow to be what it is today. It is humbling to see how Claude Code has become a core dev tool for so many engineers, how enthusiastic the community is, and how people are using it for all sorts of things from coding, to devops, to research, to non-technical use cases. This technology is alien and magical, and it makes it so much easier for people to build and create. Increasingly, code is no longer the bottleneck.

A year ago, Claude struggled to generate bash commands without escaping issues. It worked for seconds or minutes at a time. We saw early signs that it may become broadly useful for coding one day.

Fast forward to today. In the last thirty days, I landed 259 PRs -- 497 commits, 40k lines added, 38k lines removed. Every single line was written by Claude Code + Opus 4.5. Claude consistently runs for minutes, hours, and days at a time (using Stop hooks). Software engineering is changing, and we are entering a new period in coding history. And we're still just getting started..

items.title: We are hiring a Head of Preparedness. This is a critical role at an important time; models are impro...
items.content:
We are hiring a Head of Preparedness. This is a critical role at an important time; models are improving quickly and are now capable of many great things, but they are also starting to present some real challenges. The potential impact of models on mental health was something we saw a preview of in 2025; we are just now seeing models get so good at computer security they are beginning to find critical vulnerabilities.
 
We have a strong foundation of measuring growing capabilities, but we are entering a world where we need more nuanced understanding and measurement of how those capabilities could be abused, and how we can limit those downsides both in our products and in the world, in a way that lets us all enjoy the tremendous benefits.  These questions are hard and there is little precedent; a lot of ideas that sound good have some real edge cases. 
 
If you want to help the world figure out how to enable cybersecurity defenders with cutting edge capabilities while ensuring attackers can't use them for harm, ideally by making all systems more secure, and similarly for how we release biological capabilities and even gain confidence in the safety of running systems that can self-improve, please consider applying.
 
This will be a stressful job and you'll jump into the deep end pretty much immediately.

https://t.co/bnFRnDE4O7

items.title:
Very good question

Grok estimates 🍌 Nano Banana Pro cost Google about $50-$200 million just to trai...
items.content:
Very good question

Grok estimates 🍌 Nano Banana Pro cost Google about $50-$200 million just to train

Every year the models get better (and bigger), and generally require more compute (like others have said), so the next better model will cost a multiple of that, so like $500 million or even $1 billion

So unless I'd raise $500 million to train that next model I don't think it's possible, because I simply do not have $500 million lying around

Another thing is that it's starting to become clear being in the model business is generally a very bad idea for most people because the moment a better model arrives, everyone just changes their code:

from:
> 'model'=>'current-model'
to:
> 'model'=>'the-new-model'

As in, the switching cost is almost $0, so models do not have much lock in

Which is WHY I think you'll see the best models come out of BigTech, because they can afford to spend massive money on creating the best models, and then make that money back by using those models in their entire portfolio of apps (see Google)

I don't think long term as a AI model startup you can keep up with that, because they 1) can't raise enough money for the trainings to compete with BigTech's infinite pockets, 2) can't survive the moment a better model comes around, 3) they don't have the front end and users to get a moat

What that means for my AI apps though is that it might be better I don't have my own models because I don't face the financial risk of training a model that's outdated in 6 months, and I just keep updating to whatever new model comes out (yes like a wrapper)

Being a niche AI app like my app Photo AI is, I can actually offer features that make it better than a general AI experience you'd have on ChatGPT or Gemini so it can remain a long-term business that way by specializing on a specific area of people photography
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Comprehensive analysis of AI model economics: Grok estimates Google's model cost $50-200M to train, future models may cost $500M-1B, switching costs are near zero creating no lock-in, BigTech will dominate model creation while niche AI apps can survive as specialized wrappers
items.reasoning: Excellent strategic analysis with concrete numbers, explains why model businesses are challenging, provides framework for thinking about AI startup positioning. High engagement (75k views, 320 likes). Valuable original thinking

items.title: I've consulted for 100+ companies over the last 3 years, and here are some of my personal favorite r...
items.content:
I've consulted for 100+ companies over the last 3 years, and here are some of my personal favorite recommendations:

(You'd be shocked at how many developers outside the online bubble need help.)

1. Some teams don't use any code versioning system. I know this is hard to believe, but I have witnesses. Honestly, this one is not common, but I've seen it with my own eyes.

2. Testing culture is rare. An easy way to improve what a team does is to teach them how to write automated unit and integration tests.

3. Spreadsheets are the most popular solution I've seen in the wild. For example, one of my most common recommendations is to use MLFlow to track experiments and version models.

4. Most teams always want to implement the technically correct solution for a problem. I've gotten very good at identifying solutions that meet many more constraints (like budget, timeline, team ability, perception, etc.) I call this "problem framing", and it's of huge help for companies.

5. I always recommend dev containers to those teams where each person uses a different operating system and struggles with configuration and portability.

6. Try to scale an application without spending time on observability and traceability. Most of the time, this is as easy as logging the right information. Sometimes you can spend time setting up the right tools for more serious observability.

7. In machine learning systems (90% of the projects I deal with), monitoring is always an afterthought. I've gotten pretty good at helping teams integrate with Evidently AI.

8. I spend a ton of time helping teams build end-to-end, repeatable, and automatable workflows with fill-in-the-blank placeholders they can complete later on. For example, building a training pipeline that starts with data processing and ends with model deployment.

Many different practices always come up with different teams:

• How to implement CI/CD
• How to version datasets
• How to know what "done" means
• How to manage secrets properly
• How to manage configuration settings
• How to configure logs
• How to test in production (a/b testing, shadow deployments, etc)
• ...

People working for big tech companies are years ahead of everyone else, but the market for this knowledge outside big tech is huge.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Comprehensive consulting insights from 100+ companies: teams lacking version control, missing testing culture, spreadsheets over proper tools, need for problem framing, dev containers recommendation, observability gaps, ML monitoring as afterthought, importance of e2e pipelines
items.reasoning: Highly valuable real-world insights about ML team practices, gaps, and recommendations. High engagement (42k views), practical and actionable advice from experienced consultant

items.title: When I left science and academia for tech I still wanted to utilize my *analytical* and scientific r...
items.content: When I left science and academia for tech I still wanted to utilize my *analytical* and scientific reasoning skills to the largest extent possible. Unfortunately pretty much every tech job that I came across just pushed you hard into becoming another SWE. Your worth and your output were consistently based on the number of the lines of code you wrote, even for data science projects where code was just a convenient representation of your work, and not the core "product". I am so glad that this age of SWE supremacist inanity is finally coming to the end.

items.title: When Salesforce says the enterprise needs deterministic systems, @massoudmaestro lays out what it is...
items.content:
When Salesforce says the enterprise needs deterministic systems, @massoudmaestro lays out what it is talking about. 

It took a while to get him to really explain what he's building, a new kind of object-oriented programming, which he used to build a new project management system. Each object has a tiny AI model embedded in it. 

Which is not an LLM that hallucinates. It makes building new enterprise software possible, and, so, is a big idea.

I'll have Grok lay out what you will learn (see comments for that), but I get a bit rude with him because I wasn't getting what he was trying to lay out at about 47 minutes in which is where he really starts explaining it well.

https://t.co/D2pQWy6uH4

items.title: @realVeshnu @arian_ghashghai To understand the answers to that, you have to look at how we failed in...
items.content:
@realVeshnu @arian_ghashghai To understand the answers to that, you have to look at how we failed in the drone market. In that sector, the Chinese were simply able to build things better and cheaper. There are several reasons for that:

1. The retail infrastructure in Shenzhen:
   They have a massive, multi-story electronics store where you can find any part needed to build anything. This means you can go in during the morning and have a prototype finished by the afternoon. In contrast, we have to wait two or three days for Amazon to deliver everything in America.

2. Manufacturing density:
   If you need to produce something, there are a thousand factories in Shenzhen or the surrounding area. That isn't true in America. Here, we might have a single Tesla factory in San Francisco, but there are very few facilities that can scale up to manufacture robots by the millions.

3. The university system and research talent:
   If you look at my AI community list on X (which consists of AI researchers), you'll notice a significant number of Chinese names. They have stepped up their innovation and education game while we haven't.

Ultimately, it comes down to the ability to manufacture things at scale at a much lower price point than we can in America. I keep hearing that same sentiment over and over again from the robotics community in San Francisco.

One last thing to consider is consumer demand. China has 10 cities bigger than New York. People live in very small houses and are crammed together in skyscrapers, which isn't true in most places in America. 

This environment creates a much hungrier appetite for new ideas and innovation in China. That massive internal market lets companies get started and quickly reach scale—companies like Insta360, among others.

items.content: Maybe, maybe not. I've been trying to "evangelize" the non-tech people I come across in my life about the imminent transformation, but most of them don't get it. And unfortunately there have been too many "boy cries wolf" events over the past three years, so most of them are pretty jaded with any kind of prognostication. Plus, people in tech generally *overestimate* how much of a *direct* impact tech has on the rest of the economy. There are many reasons for it, from inertia, to regulation, to the fact that many sectors of the economy are just glorified grifter fiefdoms that are intrinsically opposed to any kind of change. My take is that only of the AI can figure out a way to go *around* those obstacles, then we'll really have a major economic transition.

items.title: We've all finished a chapter only to realize we can't remember what we just read. This points to som...
items.content:
We've all finished a chapter only to realize we can't remember what we just read. This points to something decades of research has confirmed: passive reading is surprisingly ineffective for learning.

# The control effect

Markant et al. (2014) stripped away different aspects of self-directed learning to find what actually matters. They have found that even just pressing a button when ready to see the next item—with no control over content or duration—significantly enhanced recognition memory.

The researchers suggested this works because controlling when you see new information lets you coordinate stimulus presentation with your own attentional state. When you decide when to advance, your brain is better prepared to encode what comes next.

# Self-pacing and strategy

Tullis and Benjamin (2011) showed that self-paced learners outperformed those who studied for the same total time but couldn't control their pace. The benefit was strongest for learners who spent more time on difficult material—a "discrepancy reduction" strategy. Self-pacing isn't just about having control; it's about using it to allocate attention where it's needed.

# Why agency matters

DuBrow et al. (2019) found that choice are inherently rewarding. Items learned when participants could make a choice (even an inconsequential one) were remembered better, and there was a correlation between how much someone's preference increased for chosen items and how much their memory improved. Agency engages value-based brain systems that strengthen consolidation.

Ding et al. (2021) extended this to incidental memory—showing that even when participants weren't trying to memorize, having control over the task improved later recognition, particularly for items processed quickly.

# ChapterPal

I programmed @ChapterPal to implement these principles: gradual text reveal controlled by the reader, AI-generated comprehension quizzes inserted during reading, regular guess-this-blurred-term puzzles, and contextual Q&A for engaging with difficult passages. 

The quizzes and puzzles align with research showing that testing and guessing strengthens retention, while the self-paced reveal directly implements the minimal agency sufficient to enhance memory.

# References

- Tullis & Benjamin (2011). On the effectiveness of self-paced learning. Journal of Memory and Language. https://t.co/8UKY996cxK
- Markant et al. (2014). Deconstructing the effect of self-directed study on episodic memory. Memory & Cognition. https://t.co/TxJlrDlALk
- DuBrow et al. (2019). A common mechanism underlying choice's influence on preference and memory. Psychonomic Bulletin & Review. https://t.co/7pkF2jUAQD
- Ding et al. (2021). The effect of choice on intentional and incidental memory. Learning & Memory. https://t.co/qr09dvdlBW

A demo of puzzles and Q&A's on ChapterPal:

items.title: The fact that coding is now available to ~6 billion people connected to the internet, yet it's still...
items.content:
The fact that coding is now available to ~6 billion people connected to the internet, yet it's still only billionaires who are making billions, is proof that it was never about a lack of skills.

It has been and still is about a lack of new ideas.

A comparison of the AI bubble to the dotcom bubble is grossly incorrect.

During the dotcom bubble, the Web was bursting with ideas. The internet was just too small for all of them to survive long enough.

Today, the Web is as big as it could physically be, but there isn't a single new idea.

items.title: @sha0nk As much as I hate the Meta glasses, the armband is actually a really interesting piece of te...
items.content:
@sha0nk As much as I hate the Meta glasses, the armband is actually a really interesting piece of technology. It can tell which fingers people are touching together, which is something a camera can't see from the front of the glasses.

It can also detect whether you're swiping your thumb up, down, left, or right, and use those gestures to control a user interface. Typeless.

@Ebastos Yes, you are right: this is exactly what many people do already. The skills you are missing:

- how to market yourself
- how to close a new customer
- how to be patient 

I don’t think I’m qualified to talk much about this, because these things come sort of natural to me, but I’d start practicing how to tell other people your value.

It sounds simple, but this is hugely valuable and most people suck at it. 

Here is a recommendation: read the book “How to Split the Difference”. It made a huge difference for me on how to negotiate and properly convey information.

items.title: What is OpenSearch? Good question! Google provides lots of information about it: https://t.co/n7UafR...
items.content:
What is OpenSearch? Good question! Google provides lots of information about it: https://t.co/n7UafRvRc4
 ★ ★ 
This 5-★ book from @PacktDataML provides a great Guide to using OpenSearch and its many applications: https://t.co/354NCwC91R
 ★ ★ 
Google says: "OpenSearch is an open-source search and analytics suite that provides scalable full-text search, real-time application monitoring, log analytics, security analytics, and vector database capabilities. Derived from Elasticsearch as a fork, it offers a community-driven, Apache 2.0-licensed solution for data-intensive applications, along with OpenSearch Dashboards for data visualization and exploration. OpenSearch is known for its high availability, performance, and flexibility, allowing users to analyze, visualize, and build data-driven applications across various use cases."
★ ★
𝓑𝓸𝓸𝓴  𝓓𝓮𝓼𝓬𝓻𝓲𝓹𝓽𝓲𝓸𝓷:

From seasoned data professionals managing billions of records to aspiring analysts exploring diverse datasets, this guide is for users at all levels who want to make the most of OpenSearch's capabilities and functionalities. Written by distinguished AWS Solutions Architects Jon Handler, Ph.D., a former search engine developer, Prashant Agrawal, a search specialist, and Soujanya Konka, an expert in large-scale data migrations, this guide brings together deep technical expertise with practical, hands-on knowledge of implementing OpenSearch in real-world scenarios.

Starting with an introduction to OpenSearch, you’ll get to grips with the key features before delving into essential topics such as installing OpenSearch, ingesting data, crafting queries, visualizing results, ensuring security, and optimizing performance. Each concept is accompanied by practical examples and tutorials, allowing you to grasp the material through hands-on experience.
items.author: @KirkDBorne
items.summary: Kirk Borne promotes an OpenSearch book, providing detailed description of OpenSearch as open-source search/analytics suite with vector database capabilities, forked from Elasticsearch
items.reasoning: Promotional but educational content about OpenSearch's capabilities including vector database features relevant to AI applications. Decent engagement from credible data science voice.

items.title: 💬 Here's the demo of https://t.co/M1hEUBAynC's PC running Windows 3.11 (from 1993) talking to https:...
items.content:
💬 Here's the demo of https://t.co/M1hEUBAynC's PC running Windows 3.11 (from 1993) talking to https://t.co/3zBxJcjapD Apple Computer running MacOS 7.1 (from 1992) both running inside your browser

It's crazy how fast the messages arrive, I'd have expected some delay because of the layers it has to go through

It goes from a PC/Mac emulator inside WebAssembly in JS sending it via an emulated modem on COM1 port with emulated TCP/IP over WebSockets then routed via a PPP daemon to the real internet and to the reverse engineered America Online server and then back again to the other computer like that

But everything happens in literally milliseconds

Modern day computing and the internet is truly insanely fast 😊
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Technical demo showing Windows 3.11 and MacOS 7.1 communicating via emulated modems through WebAssembly, WebSockets, and reverse-engineered AOL servers in browser
items.reasoning: Impressive technical achievement with 100k views, but not directly AI/ML related - more about retro computing emulation

Pathology has barely changed for decades.

→ Glass slides
→ Physical microscopes
→ Manual handoffs
→ Local-only collaboration

Now imagine this instead :
→ Cases reviewed in the cloud
→ High-performance digital imaging
→ Doctors collaborating globally in real time

That is the quiet digital shift happening right now.

items.title: @konstructivizm This is misleading. Astronomers have believed for almost 100 years that the Milky Wa...
items.content:
@konstructivizm This is misleading. Astronomers have believed for almost 100 years that the Milky Way disk oscillates vertically. No astronomer alive has ever believed it to be a flat, static disk.

The first hypotheses of vertical oscillations in the Galactic disk emerged from early theoretical models by astronomers like Oort (1932), using the "slab" model, leading to later work by Mathur (1990), Weinberg (1991), and others.

The new research presents clear observational evidence for this very natural gravitational dynamics behavior. That’s great and very important. But it isn’t like a surprising unexpected discovery. It’s called experimental scientific research.

https://t.co/e4NAQj6Qhk
items.author: @KirkDBorne
items.summary: Kirk Borne provides detailed scientific correction about Milky Way disk oscillation research, explaining the 100-year history of this theory in astronomy
items.reasoning: High engagement (148 likes, 10K views) showing author credibility, but off-topic from AI/ML focus

items.title: @OAndroot @Chaos2Cured @theo @Stanford Well, I have tried to do that and they just don't want to hea...
items.content:
@OAndroot @Chaos2Cured @theo @Stanford Well, I have tried to do that and they just don't want to hear anything that takes on their world view.

The problem is that there are a ton of lawsuits and lawyers killed their favorite model. They don't see that this model is harmful and aren't willing to acknowledge that sometimes technology comes along to make humans worse. They think "I'm fine" and don't think of the greater consequences. 

It's like arguing consciousness. Never leads to anywhere really productive, because everyone is convinced their world view is correct and aren't willing to change. 

Anyway, I've said enough and have wasted enough time on this issue. 

I'd rather talk with people who are using Anthropic Claude to actually build things rather than trying to get a company to bring back a model that causes harm to humanity.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer discusses lawsuits affecting AI models and debates about harmful vs beneficial AI, expressing frustration with unproductive consciousness debates.
